title-group.article-title: Failure Predictions for DP Steel Cross-die Test using Anisotropic Damage

article-meta.aff: 1Materials Innovation Institute (M2i) P.O. Box 5008, 2600 GA Delft, The Netherlands
2Faculty of Engineering Technology, University of Twente, P.O. Box 217, 7500 AE Enschede, The Netherlands

author-notes.corresp: *Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. E-mail: m.s.niazi@m2i.nl

abstract.p: The Lemaitre's continuum damage model is well known in the field of damage mechanics. The anisotropic damage model given by Lemaitre is relatively simple, applicable to nonproportional loads and uses only four damage parameters. The hypothesis of strain equivalence is used to map the effective stress to the nominal stress. Both the isotropic and anisotropic damage models from Lemaitre are implemented in an in-house implicit finite element code. The damage model is coupled with an elasto-plastic material model using anisotropic plasticity (Hill-48 yield criterion) and strain-rate dependent isotropic hardening. The Lemaitre continuum damage model is based on the small strain assumption; therefore, the model is implemented in an incremental co-rotational framework to make it applicable for large strains. The damage dissipation potential was slightly adapted to incorporate a different damage evolution behavior under compression and tension. A tensile test and a low-cycle fatigue test were used to determine the damage parameters. The damage evolution was modified to incorporate strain rate sensitivity by making two of the damage parameters a function of strain rate. The model is applied to predict failure in a cross-die deep drawing process, which is well known for having a wide variety of strains and strain path changes. The failure predictions obtained from the anisotropic damage models are in good agreement with the experimental results, whereas the predictions obtained from the isotropic damage model are slightly conservative. The anisotropic damage model predicts the crack direction more accurately compared to the predictions based on principal stress directions using the isotropic damage model. The set of damage parameters, determined in a uniaxial condition, gives a good failure prediction under other triaxiality conditions.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Global fuel crisis and increasing public safety concerns are compelling the automobile industry to design high-strength and low-weight automobiles. The development of Advanced High Strength Steels (AHSS), also known as Dual Phase (DP) steels, is a big step forward in achieving this goal. Sheet metal forming is the most widely used manufacturing process in the automotive industry. Many sheet metal parts, which were first manufactured from traditional forming steels, are now being manufactured from DP steels (Senuma, 2001). DP steels have a higher strength in comparison to the traditional forming steels and thus gives a high strength-to-weight ratio. Apart from the structural stability, the ductility of the material is important for the manufacturing process. The ductility of the DP steel is higher compared to traditional forming steel of the same strength. However, to achieve high strength-to-weight ratio, the DP steels shall replace the low strength forming steels. When the ductility of these two materials are compared, then DP steels have lower ductility. The lower formability of DP steel is attributed to damage development. The microstructure of DP steels has martensitic phase islands embedded in a soft ferritic matrix. The ferrite phase contributes toward, the ductility, whereas the martensite phase enhances the strength. When the material is plastically deformed, the different deformation behaviors of these phases give rise to voids and cracks within the martensite phase or at the interisfaces of both phases (Hoefnagels et al., 2008, Tasan et al., 2009, 2010). Banded martensitic phase is present in these materials. Localization of these banded martensitic micro structure was observed during deformation (Ghadbeigi et al., 2001; Tasan et al., 2010). It is very clear that damage plays an important role in limiting the formability of DP steels. Therefore, damage material models are required for failure prediction and to determine the forming limit curve (FLC) for these advanced materials (Chow and Jie, 2009).

The development of advanced materials not only requires advanced material models for predictions but also requires updating/replacing the traditional experimental techniques to determine the formability of materials. Arelatively new experiment, the cross-die drawing test, has been devised (Atzema et al., 2004). Figure 1(a) shows the final product obtained from the test. The cross-die forming process covers a wide range of triaxialities and thus, it is very useful for determining the formability. Apart from the wide range of triaxialities, some regions of the blank undergo severe strain path changes. Figure 1(b) shows the Strain Path Change Indicator (SPCI) distribution for one quarter of the cross-die test. This result was obtained from a finite element analysis simulation of the cross-die test with elasto-plastic material model and isotropic hardening (van Riel, 2009). The regions where the SPCI is ‘1’ remain proportional, whereas the regions where SPCI is ‘0’ undergo an orthogonal strain path change and regions with SPCI of ‘−1’ means a complete reversal of the strain path. The complex nature of this drawing process makes it a suitable candidate for the validation of advanced material models for sheet metal forming processes. Figure 1.
Cross-die test: (a) final product atzema et al (2004) and (b) strain path change indicator.

The inclusion of the phenomenon of damage in continuum mechanics originated almost half a century ago when Kachanov (1958) introduced a one-dimensional variable to represent material damage. Kachanov also introduced the concept of effective stress. This concept is based on considering a fictitious undamaged configuration of a body and comparing it with the actual damaged configuration. He originally formulated his theory using simple uni-axial tension. Following Kachanov's work, researchers applied continuum damage mechanics to their own fields of expertise, like brittle materials (Krajcinovic and Foneska, 1981; Krajcinovic, 1983, 1996; Voyiadjis et al., 2009) and ductile materials (Lemaitre, 1984, 1985; Kachanov, 1986; Murakami, 1988; Chow and Wang, 1987a). In the last two decades, continuum damage mechanics has been applied extensively to plasticity (Lubarda and Krajcinovic, 1995; Voyiadjis and Kattan, 1999; Voyiadjis and Park, 1999; Voyiadjis and Deliktas, 2000; Chow and Wang, 2004). Damage is defined as an internal state variable in the irreversible thermodynamic framework. The process of damage in material will dissipate energy. Any damage evolution can be defined as far as this condition is met. The damage variable can be selected as a scalar quantity or as any even ordered tensor. Recently, a comparative study on different damage variables was carried out by Voyiadjis and Kattan, (2009). The isotropic (scalar) definition of damage is the most simple to implement and thus has been widely used by researchers. Researchers have already realized that the process of damage is anisotropic in general (Chow and Wang, 1987b; Krajcinovic, 1996; Lee et al., 2004). To introduce anisotropy in damage, one must define a tensorial damage variable. The question raises that what order of the tensor shall be chosen. The restriction to even ordered tensor is imposed by the basic definition of damage (Krajcinovic, 1996). Theoretically, an infinite order damage tensor will give accurate predictions. Selection of any lower order will introduce approximations in the predictions. The higher the order of the damage tensor selected is, the more accurate will be the predictions (and the more complex will be the formulations). A sixth-order tensor may give better predictions in comparison to a second-order tensor but at a cost of a very high complexity. Despite of the complexity, sixth- and fourth-order damage tensors have been implemented by researchers in the form of fabric tensors, a more physical form of the damage tensor (Krajcinovic, 1996; Voyiadjis and Kattan, 2006). Fourth-or sixth-order damage tensors are necessary when applying the model on materials like rocks (Krajcinovic, 1996). For ductile metals, where damage is driven by plastic strains, selection of an orthotropic damage anisotropy is sufficient which requires only a second-order damage tensor. The scope of this article is restricted to ductile metals and therefore a second-order damage tensor is selected.

Anisotropy in damage can be classified into two categories; Material Induced Anisotropy in Damage (MIAD) and Load Induced Anisotropy in Damage (LIAD). MIAD is related to the anisotropy in distribution and shape of second phase particles and is governed by void/crack nucleation. Figure 2(a) shows the true stress–strain curves for a sheet metal in the rolling and transverse directions. Initially, the mechanical response of the material is the same in rolling and transverse directions but the response starts to deviate after some amount of straining. This deviation is attributed to the anisotropy of second phase particles in the rolling and transverse directions. An example of MIAD can be found in (Tyler-Street and Luyten, 2009). LIAD is related to the loading direction of the material. Generally, damage grows faster in the direction of maximum principal stress irrespective of the anisotropy in the second phase particles and/or microstructure. As an example, the schematic in Figure 2(b) shows how the stress state induces anisotropy in void growth. Most of the available anisotropic continuum damage models account for LIAD only, as the damage parameters used in the damage evolution law are direction independent. Figure 2.
Two types of induced damage anisotropy: (a) material induced (Courtesy TNO) and (b) load induced.

Researchers have developed continuum anisotropic damage models by considering the underlying physics at the microlevel. Hammi has developed a model (Hammi et al., 2004; Hammi and Horstemeyer, 2007) which gives separate evolution terms for void nucleation, growth, and coalescence. Another physical approach toward damage mechanics is the usage of fabric tensors (Krajcinovic, 1996; Voyiadjis and Kattan, 2006). The fabric tensors are developed based on the microcrack densities. Although these models are based on the real underlying physics, they have some disadvantages. In general, a large number of complex micrographic experiments, a well-equipped laboratory and skilled personnel are necessary to find the required damage parameters of the physical, based damage model. An alternative option is to use a semi-phenomenological approach, i.e. to determine the damage model parameters based on macroscale experiments and not considering the actual damage phenomenon i.e. void nucleation, growth and coalescence or micro crack density distribution. Simple mechanical testing methods are sufficient to determine the parameters in these semi-phenomenological models (Lemaitre and Desmorat, 2005). However, the physics of damage at the micro-level is not accounted for in these semi-phenomenological models and therefore some physical effects cannot be captured by these models. For example, in cast A356 aluminum alloy, the void nucleation rate increases with the decrease in temperature but the coalescence rate decreases with decrease in temperature (Hammi and Horstemeyer, 2007). This effect cannot be simulated using a semi-phenomenological model because the nucleation, growth, and coalescence of voids do not evolve separately. Despite of their, to some extent, compromise in accuracy, semi-phenomenological damage models are more widely used than physically based models due to their simplicity. Some-well known semi-phenomenological anisotropic damage models are developed by Murakami, Chow, and Lemaitre. Murakami, (1988) introduced anisotropic damage in the framework of large deformations. The hypothesis of elastic strain energy equivalence was utilized by Chow for the implementation of anisotropic damage (Chow and Wang, 1987a; Chow and Lu 1989; Grammenoudis et al., 2009a,b; Voyiadjis et al., 2009). The use of the energy equivalence principle requires the definition of effective strain along with the effective stress. On the other hand, Lemaitre and Desmorat (2005) opted for the hypothesis of strain equivalence, which requires only the definition of effective stress. This makes the formulation relatively simpler. Recently, Lemaitre's anisotropic damage model coupled with a necking criterion, was implemented by Teixeira et al. (2009) for the prediction of FLC.

In this article, Lemaitre's anisotropic damage model will be applied for failure predictions of the cross-die test. In ‘Anisotropic damage model’ section, a brief description of the Lemaitre's anisotropic damage model and the changes made in the damage evolution law are given. In ‘Implementation’ section, the 3D-implementation of this anisotropic damage model in an in-house implicit finite element code is presented. ‘Damage parameter identification’ section presents the determination of damage parameters for a specific grade of pre-production DP steel from tensile tests and low-cycle fatigue tests. In ‘Application: Cross-die test’ section, the damage models and the determined damage parameters are used to predict failure in the cross-die test. The simulation results are compared with experimental results. The article is finalized with conclusions.

sec.title: ANISOTROPIC DAMAGE MODEL
sec.p: As starting point, the anisotropic damage model of Lemaitre and Desmorat (2005) is used in this research. A brief description of the model is given here. Thermodynamics is the basic ingredient of a continuum damage model. A good description of irreversible thermodynamics can be found in Yang et al., (2010). A short description for the thermodynamics used in this model is given here. A partial Legendre transform of the Helmholtz–free energy was performed to get the Gibbs specific free enthalpy. This is done to select stress as an independent variable, as it will be more convenient while dealing with the state law of elasticity. The Gibbs specific free enthalpy is given by (1) where (2) (3) Several assumptions are made to simplify the implementation of the model. The process is assumed to be isothermal, a small strain formulation with an additive split of the strain tensor is taken, elasticity is assumed to be isotropic and only isotropic hardening will be considered.

An equivalence principle is required to map the state variables from a damaged material configuration to an undamaged fictitious material configuration. Different researchers have opted for different equivalence hypotheses. The stress equivalence was introduced by Simo and Ju (1987), Lemaitre and Desmorat (2005) extensively developed the strain equivalence and the energy equivalence was used by Chow and Wang (1987a). For this study, the most simple hypothesis, i.e. the hypothesis of strain equivalence has been used. The elastic potential based on this hypothesis is defined by Lemaitre and Desmorat (2005) (4) where η is the hydrostatic sensitivity parameter and H the second-order damage effect tensor defined as a function of the second-order damage tensor D. (5) In this thermodynamic model, εij is the observable state variable with σij as the associated variable, εijp, r, and Dij the internal state variables with −σij, R, and −Yij as the associated variables, respectively. r represents the independent isotropic hardening variable and R the isotropic hardening modulus. Yis the second-order damage energy release rate. The observable state variables and their associated variables are defined using the state law, i.e. using the state potential ‘ψ*’, whereas the internal state variables are defined by a dissipation potential ‘F’. The state law is given by (6) where δij are the components of Kronecker delta. The dissipation potential is defined by (7) (8) Where f is the plastic dissipation potential and FD the damage dissipation potential.

The Clausius–Duhem equation can be written as (9) The second law of thermodynamics is satisfied if the dissipation potential is selected as a convex function of the associated variables. The dissipation potential for damage ‘FD’ is given by Lemaitre and Desmorat (2005) (10) where |..| applied to a tensor means the absolute value in terms of the principal components. Y¯ is the effective damage energy release rate given by (11) where σ~eq is the effective equivalent stress, based on the effective Cauchy stress given by (12) R¯v is a triaxiality factor defined by (13) The plastic potential ‘f ’ is given by (14) where the flow stress is defined by σf = σf0 + R. The evolution laws for the internal variables are defined using the normality rule (15) (16) (17) Using Equations (15) and (16). (18) Equation (18) is valid when the damage threshold is reached, i.e. εeqp>εDp. The term εeqp is the equivalent plastic strain which represents the accumulated plastic strain in a scalar form. The evolution of εeqp is given by (19) A mesocrack is initiated when damage reaches a critical value, i.e. max(DI) ≥ Dc, where DI represents the principal damage values of the damage tensor. The initiation of mesocrack is assumed to be the point of failure.

The damage parameters used in this model are S,s,εDp, η, and Dc. The hydrostatic sensitivity parameter η has been measured by Lemaitre for many materials. It was found to be near to 3 for almost all materials; therefore, η is taken equal to 3 in this study. The other four parameters are determined from a uniaxial test and a low-cycle fatigue test using the fast identification method given by Lemaitre and Desmorat, 2005. The identification of the damage parameters for DP600 can be found in ‘Damage parameter identification’ section.

In metals, damage is mainly due to voids. Voids cannot grow under negative hydrostatic stresses. Only nucleation of voids can be a possibility under negative triaxiality. The difference of damage evolution for metals under tension and compression needs to be incorporated in this model. A parameter uf is included in the model, which phenomenologically describes the different damage evolutions under tension and compression. The parameter S in (18) is modified to Sc, for negative triaxialities, using the relation (20) and the damage evolution law given in (18) is modified to (21) The parameter uf can be determined using a compression test. In this study, the value of uf is taken high enough to produce no damage under negative triaxialities. This is a good assumption for ductile metals.

To satisfy the second law of thermodynamics (9), it must be shown that the energy dissipated due to damage is positive or zero. (22) The damage dissipation potential has been selected such that the damage evolution becomes a function of the absolute principal values of plastic strain rate tensor, (18). Therefore, D· remains always positive definite. To satisfy (22), Y shall also be positive definite. Since ‘Y’ is an associated variable to damage, it can be determined using the state potential of (1). (23) Using (4) and Equations (111), (112), and (118) of Appendix 2 and transforming into tensorial form one obtains (24) The expression derived in (24) gives a positive definite tensor if and only if ‘H’ is positive definite. The definition of H given in (5) shows that H will be positive definite for all practical cases (max(DI) < 1). Therefore, the selection of the state potential and damage dissipation potential satisfies the second law of thermodynamics. Equations (1) – (4) give the state potentials used in this model. Equations (7), (8), (10), and (14) give the dissipation potentials used in this model. Equations (15) – (18) are the evolution equations for the internal state variables. An important aspect of this model is the definition of the effective stress (12). Generally, the effective stress for anisotropic damage is defined by (25) where M is the fourth-order damage effect tensor, which is a function of damage and is defined by (26) where D¯¯ is the fourth-order damage tensor. Working with a fourth-order damage tensor is not trivial; therefore, usually a second-order damage tensor and damage effect tensor is defined. This modifies (25) into (27) In general, (27) will not yield a symmetric effective stress tensor. Therefore, symmetrization of ~ is required. Different methods are used by researchers to symmetrize the effective stress. Lemaitre defined the symmetrization of the effective stress by splitting it into the deviatoric and hydrostatic part, as mentioned in (12). This definition complicates the formulation to some extent; therefore, it is convenient to extract the equivalent fourth-order damage effect tensor M from (12). (28) Here, ⊗ presents a special tensor multiplication given by (29) Equations (25) and (12) are exactly equivalent when (28) is used as the fourth -order damage effect tensor. The detail derivation of Equations (28) and (29) can be found in Appendix 1.

sec.title: IMPLEMENTATION
sec.p: The implementation of a material model in a finite element code is carried out through a stress (state variables) update routine. For a given strain increment, the new stress and damage state is found in a coupled manner. The evolution equations (Equations (15–18)) are implicit and cannot be solved analytically. Therefore, an iterative numerical scheme is required to update the state variables incrementally. In this implementation, an Euler Backward numerical scheme is used. The first step is to transform the differential equations into difference equations.

The total strain increment can be written as the sum of the incremental elastic strain and incremental plastic strain. (30) The effective stress can be written in the difference form as: (31) where E is the fourth-order isotropic elasticity tensor. Using (15), the incremental plastic strain can be written as: (32) Substituting Equations (32) and (31) into Equation (30) gives (33) Equation (18) is used to write the equation for the damage increment (34) In the forthcoming equations, subscripts and superscripts are used to denote the step and iteration number. The subscript ‘n’ represents the increment number. The derivative or function with a subscript ‘n + 1’ represents that the derivative or function is evaluated at the end of the step. The superscript ‘i’ denotes the iteration number within the step n. The symbols without any subscript or superscript are constant throughout the step. RR…i gives the residual in the iterative equation in the ith step.

Employing the iterative Euler Backward scheme on Equations (33) and (34) and on the yield function gives: (35) (36) (37) It can be observed from Equations (35) – (37), that the iteration is done on three independent variables, i.e. effective stress, damage, and plastic multiplier. This requires an update of these independent variables every iteration. (38) (39) (40) where δ(.)ni represents the iterative increment in the independent variable (.) in the ith iteration during the increment step n. The values of δσ~ni, δDni, and δλni should be such that the residuals, i.e. RRσ~i, RRDi and RRλi shall vanish. This condition can be achieved by solving (41) for δσ~ni, δDni, and δλni. (41) Linearizing Equation (35) gives: (42) Substituting Equation (35) into Equation (42) and neglecting products of δσ~ni, and/or δDni and/or δλni gives a relation between RRσ~i and the variations in σ~, D,andλ (43) Linearizing Equation (36) gives: (44) Substituting Equation (36) into Equation (44) and neglecting products of δσ~ni, and/or δDni and/or δλni gives a relation between RRDi and the variations in σ~, D, and λ (45) Equation (45) contains the derivative of effective damage energy release withrespect to the effective stress. This can be found by substituting Equation (13) in Equation (11) and differentiating with respect to the effective stress. (46) Linearizing Equation (37) gives: (47) Substituting Equation (37) into Equation (47) gives a relation between RRλi and the variations in σ~, D, and λ (48) Arranging Equations (43), (45) and (48) in matrix finally yields (49) where the 13x13 matrix ‘MM’ is given by (50) For a given strain increment, initially the residuals are calculated using Equations (35) – (37). If any of the residuals is greater in magnitude than the convergence criteria, then the state variables will be updated using Equations (38) – (40) and (49). The residuals will be checked for convergence again using the updated variables. This iteration will be carried out until the solution converges.

As can be seen from Equation (50), six partial derivatives of the dissipation potential ‘f ’ (Equation (14)) are required in order to solve Equation (49), i.e. ∂f∂σ~, ∂f∂σ, ∂f∂λ, ∂f∂D, ∂2f∂σ~∂σ, and ∂2f∂D∂σ. The derivatives of ‘f ’ will be determined for the Hill-48 yield criterion in the next section.

sec.title: Partial Differentiation of Plastic Dissipation Potential ‘f ’
sec.p: The plastic dissipation potential reads: (51) where P is the Hill parameter matrix and σf is the plastic strain and plastic strain rate-dependent flow stress given by (52) The partial derivatives are given as follows.

Since the dissipation potential is based on the fictitious ‘undamaged material’; therefore, (53) The partial derivative of f with respect to the effective stress is given by: (54) Since the Hill-48 plasticity model is independent of the hydrostatic stresses, the nominal normal to the yield surface can be defined by taking the deviatoric component only. (55) where Q is a fourth-order tensor given by (56) Here, ⊗ presents a special tensor multiplication given by Equation (29). Thedetailed derivation of Equations (56) and (29) can be found in Appendix 1.

The partial derivative of f with respect to the plastic multiplier is obtained using the definition of equivalent plastic strain based on work hardening: (57) Differentiating Equation (55) with respect to the effective stress will give (58) Differentiating Equation (55) with respect to the damage gives (59) The derivative of Q with respect to D (including symmetrization) is given by (60) where (61) The derivative of H2 with respect to D is determined as (62) The detailed derivation of Equations (61) and (62) can be found in Appendix 2.

sec.title: Stiffness Matrix
sec.p: The damage model is implemented in the in-house implicit finite element code, and therefore a consistent formulation for the stiffness matrix is required. Equations (49) and (50) will be used to calculate the tangent stiffness matrix for the anisotropic damage model described in the previous sections. The matrix MM (50) is divided into nine blocks: (63) Here, MM11, MM12, MM21, and MM22 are blocks of 6x6 elements each, MM13 and MM23 each are blocks of 6x1 elements, MM31 is a block of 1x6 elements, MM32 a block of 1x6 zeroes (Equation (53)), and MM33 one element. To develop a relation between the stress and strain increment, the residual for stress is taken as a small increment in strain ‘δϵ’, whereas the residuals for damage and yield surface will be set to zero in Equation (49). (64) Equation (64) can also be written in the form of four submatrices. (65) where δσ~ is the incremental effective stress due to the incremental strain δϵ. To find the tangent stiffness matrix, we must find a relationship between ‘δσ~’ and ‘δϵ’ by eliminating ‘δD’ and ‘δλ’ from Equation (65). (66) Using Equation (25), the relation between δσ~ and the incremental nominal stress δσ can be defined by (67) The tangent stiffness matrix can be derived from Equations (66) and (67) (68) Note that the material stiffness matrix is not symmetric in general.

sec.title: Co-rotational Framework
sec.p: In this study, the Lemaitre's anisotropic damage model is intended to be used for sheet metal forming which involves large deformations. However, the damage model formulation is based on small strain formulation. A small strain formulation can be used for large deformations if it is implemented in a co-rotational framework (Belytschko et al. (2006)). The co-rotational framework defines a local coordinate system for each element. In sheet metal forming simulations, it is a common practice to keep the element's local coordinate system always aligned with the rolling direction of the material. Therefore, it is also known as the material axis. The rotation of the local coordinate system is calculated in each deformation increment and the total rotation tensor (from global to local) is updated. The stress update is always carried out in the material axis, at the center of the increment (local coordinate system). The detail formulation for a co-rotational framework can be found in Belytschko et al. (2006).

sec.title: Rotation of Coordinate System
sec.p: The damage evolution law, defined in Equation (34), involves the principal plastic strain rate components. Since the damage update is coupled with the stress update (Equation (49)), the complete update procedure has to be carried out in the principal plastic strain rate coordinate system. Therefore, the local coordinate system is needed to be rotated to the principal plastic strain rate coordinate system. According to Equation (34), the principal damage rate direction coincides with the principal plastic strain rate direction. The principal plastic strain rate direction will be the same as the total strain rate direction, especially if the elastic strains are very small. Therefore, the rotation tensor can be formed using the strain rate tensor. If the strain path changes then the principal strain rate (or damage rate) direction rotates and thus the principal direction of total damage tensor also rotates.

The rotation of coordinate system is based on the formulation given in Chow et al. (2001a, b). Let us say that the local coordinate system is defined by the vectors x1, x2, and x3, whereas the principal strain rate (or damage rate) coordinate system is defined by the vectors x1t, x2t and x3t. Then, the transformation of the local coordinate system to the principal strain rate coordinate system is given by: (69) βji are the direction cosines of the xjt vector with respect to the xi vector. Let us say that the second-order tensor state variable in the element's local coordinate system is represented by A; then, the tensor operation for transformation of A to the principal strain rate coordinate system (At) is given by (70) Note that the property of rotation tensors R−1 = RT do not hold for the fourth-order operator ‘Rot’. To rotate the variables back to the local coordinates an inverse of Rot shall be used.

sec.title: DAMAGE PARAMETER IDENTIFICATION
sec.p: The DP grades of steel are proven to be very useful in crash applications. These materials show enhanced post localization strains for higher strain rates (Huh et al., 2008). Huh explains the increase in post-localization strain in terms of void volume growth and interaction. Higher strain rates shift the thermodynamics of the deformation process from isothermal to adiabatic. Due to accumulation of heat at higher strain rates, the temperature of the material increases. This increases the ductility of the material and thus allows the voids to grow larger by delaying the void coalescence process. Huh supported this hypothesis by showing micrographs of fracture surfaces at different strain rates. This shows that for DP steels, damage depends upon the strain rate. The phenomena of increased void volumes and suppression of void coalescence lead to the initiation of a meso-crack at higher void volumes. Considering the basic definition of damage, the meso-crack will be initiated at higher damage values for high strain rates. Recently, Besson (2010) has shown that using Lemaitre's damage model in combination with a strain rate-dependent hardening model will increase the damage rate, which is in contrary to the behavior of DP600. It is therefore necessary to make the Lemaitre's damage model dependent upon strain rate. To avoid thermo-mechanical coupled simulations, damage is defined as a function of strain rate with an isothermal process assumption. To incorporate the delayed meso-crack initiation, the critical damage value ‘Dc’ defined in ‘Anisotropic damage model’ section shall be made a function of strain rate. The parameter ‘s’ in the damage evolution law, (18), governs the shape of damage evolution. For most materials, especially steel, this value is larger than 2. This gives an exponential rise in damage near to failure. Physically, the exponential rise in damage is attributed to the coalescence of voids. If void coalescence is postponed under higher strain rates, then the value of ‘s’ shall also be made a function of strain rate. The dependence of ‘s’ on strain rate has to be taken such that the damage evolution changes from an exponential rise at lower strain rates to a linear rise at higher strain rates to postpone the void coalescence.

As mentioned in ‘Anisotropic damage model’ section, there are four damage parameters which have to be determined, i.e. S, s, εDp, and Dc. These parameters are identified for DP600 steel grade using the fast identification procedure given by Lemaitre and Desmorat (2005). The procedure uses data from a tensile test and a low-cyclic fatigue test. To account for the changes mentioned above, the parameter identification will be done on a very slow tensile test. This is done to make sure that strain rate does not effect the damage evolution. In this study, a tensile test was carried out at an average strain rate of 0.001s−1. The Euro-Norm tensile test specimen with the gauge length of 50 mm was selected for this purpose. The value of ‘Dc’ and ‘s’ determined from this test will be termed as reference values ‘Dc0’ and ‘s0’. The average strain rate of the tensile test will be taken as the reference strain rate ‘SR0’. Figure 3 shows the engineering stress–strain curve for the tensile test carried out at an average strain rate of 0.001/s−1. According to the fast identification method damage begins at the strain on which the ultimate stress occurs; εDp≈0.18. The critical damage value (taken as reference critical damage value in this research) is defined based on the ultimate tensile strength and the rupture stress. (71) Apart from these values, the ratio of the minimum cross-sectional area to the initial cross-sectional area was also determined from the tensile test. This value will be used as an input for determination of the other two parameters, i.e. ‘S’ and ‘s0’. Figure 3.
Tensile test at strain rate of 0.001s−1. Determination of damage parameters.

The information required from the low-cycle fatigue test is the stress amplitude, plastic strain amplitude, and the number of cycles to failure at two data points. The fatigue limit is also required in this procedure. The data from the low-cycle fatigue test are confidential and thus not presented in this article. Using all the above-mentioned data from the low-cycle fatigue test and the data obtained from the tensile test, the other two parameters were determined using the fast identification method. The values obtained are S = 1.398 and s0 ≈ 2.3.

The material parameters ‘Dc’ and ‘s’ are defined as a function of the strain rate ε·eqp and reference values Dc0 and s0. These functions are given in Equations (72) and (73), respectively. (72) (73) The functions defined in Equations (72) and (73) are selected in such a way that the change in post-localization behavior of the material with the change in strain rate levels can be simulated. The validation of these functions is given in ‘Validation of the functions’ section.

The fast identification method utilizes the assumption of isotropic damage, but the same parameters can also be used for the anisotropic damage model. The reason is that the model only takes into account the LIAD and not the MIAD. To account for MIAD, it may be necessary to determine few extra parameters, but this is out of the scope of this article.

sec.title: Plastic Yield and Hardening Parameters
sec.p: Apart from the damage parameters, the plastic yield and hardening parameters shall also be determined. From experiments, the Lankford coefficient (R-value defining plastic anisotropy) for DP600 was found near to 1.0. This shows that the material is plastically almost isotropic. Therefore, the Von Mises yield criterion was selected.

The hardening behavior of DP600 was found to be strain rate dependent. Therefore, a strain rate, dependent hardening model, the extended Bergström hardening, was selected. The extended Bergström hardening is a physical based, isothermal, strain rate-dependent, isotropic hardening model (Vegter et al., 2003). The extended Bergström model is given as: (74) where σwh and σdyn represent the strain and strain rate hardening terms, respectively. The strain hardening term is defined by: (75) where dσm, βv, ϵ0, ω, and n are the stress increment parameter, linear hardening parameter, initial strain value, remobilization parameter, and strain hardening exponent, respectively. The strain rate-dependent hardening term is defined by: (76) where σv0, k, T, ▵G0, ε·0, and p are the maximum dynamic stress, Boltzman constant, temperature, dislocation activation energy, reference strain rate parameter and strain rate hardening exponent, respectively. The parameters for extended Bergström hardening were fitted on three different strain rates, i.e. 0.001, 0.038 and 1s−1. The fit has been carried out using the true stress–strain curves up to localization. Figure 4 shows the fit of the hardening model to experiments. It shall be noted that the plots for the extended Bergström hardening are not produced with simulations. These plots are made at a single integration point using Equations (74) – (76). The fitting is carried out up to localization, because the experimental true stress–true strain curves are not valid for the non-uniform deformation condition. Figure 4.
Fitting of extended Bergström hardening parameters.

sec.title: Validation of the Parameters
sec.p:
The damage parameters at the reference strain rate, i.e. 0.001s−1 are determined without tuning the values to fit the experimental curve. Therefore, the damage parameters can be validated if the stress–strain curve given in Figure 3 can be reproduced with simulations using these parameters. For this purpose, tensile test simulations were carried out for three cases, i.e. without any damage, with the isotropic damage model, and with the anisotropic damage model. An implicit finite element in-house code was used for these simulations. A 3D solid model with four elements over the thickness was used. Figure 5 shows the complete finite element model and the dimensions of the specimen. The reference strain rate was applied to the simulations. Figure 6(a) shows the comparison of the stress–strain curves obtained from tensile simulations with the experimental stress–strain curve at the reference strain rate of 0.001s−1. The simulation carried out without a damage model clearly fails to predict the failure and considerably over predicts the maximum achievable strain. On the other hand, the simulation with the isotropic damage model slightly under predicts the maximum achievable strain. This is due to the fact that isotropic damage model produces a more severe softening effect in comparison to the anisotropic damage model. The simulation with the anisotropic damage model gives the best comparison. Figure 5.
Finite element model for the tensile test simulation. Figure 6.
Comparison of engineering stress–strain curves: simulations vs experiment: (a)0.001s−1 (b) 0.038s−1.

sec.title: Validation of the Functions
sec.p: As mentioned earlier in this section, the functions defined in Equations (72) and (73) need to be validated. For this purpose, another tensile test experiment was carried out at a strain rate of 0.038s−1. The obtained damage parameters and the defined functions in ‘Damage parameter identification’ section should reproduce this experiment as well. The same simulation inputs were used as defined in ‘valildation of the parameters’ section, only the input strain rate was changed to 0.038s−1, and the reference strain rate was defined as 0.001s−1. Figure 6(b) shows the comparison of the stress–strain curves obtained from tensile simulations with the experimental stress–strain curve at the strain rate of 0.038s−1. Again, the simulation without a damage model considerably over predicts the maximum achievable strain. The simulation with isotropic damage model under predicts the maximum achievable strain, whereas the simulation with the anisotropic damage model gives the best comparison. If the functions defined in Equations (72) and (73) are not used, then both the damage models under predict the maximum achievable strains.

sec.title: APPLICATION: CROSS-DIE TEST
sec.p: The anisotropic damage model described in ‘Anisotropic damage model’ and ‘Implementation’ sections is used to predict the failure of the pre-production DP600 material in the relatively newly developed cross-die test. The benefit of this test is that it triggers a wide variety of strains and accounts for strain path changes. These properties make this test a suitable candidate for determination of the formability of a material.

sec.title: Experiments
sec.p: The cross-die deep drawing experiments were performed on a semi-industrial press. The blanks were prepared from 1-mm thick galvanized DP600 steel sheets with a blank size of 270 × 270 mm. A suitable grade of oil was applied on both sides of the blank. The punch speed was set at 35 mm/s−1. The blank holder force was set at 483 kN. The actual blank holder force was measured with eight load cells mounted in different locations. The sum of the measured values from the eight load cells was found to be 465.7 kN, which is lower than the setpoint. The critical punch displacement for localization was found to be 39 mm. There were many tests conducted, out of which two tests were stopped at a punch displacement of 39.6 mm. Out of these two tests, one localized and developed a slight crack, whereas the other stopped just before localization. These tests are more interesting from a failure point of view as one just failed, while the other is on the verge of failure and both are on the same punch displacement. The punch force–displacement curves were obtained from these experiments.

The strain distribution was measured for the experiment that reached the critical height but did not localize. The blank was gridded with a 2.5-mm dot grid applied electrochemically. These grids were used for strain distribution measurements after drawing. The strain measurement was done with the PHASTTM photogrammetric strain measurement equipment. Figure 7(a) shows the gridded product. Figure 7(b) presents the major strain distribution for the complete product. Figure 7.
Strain distribution measurement with the PHAST™ equipment: (a) gridded product. and (b) major strain distribution.

sec.title: Finite Element Model
sec.p: To simulate the cross-die test, a finite element model was developed. Due to double symmetry, one quarter of the blank was used in the simulation. The blank consists of 11,236 hexahedron solid elements with 14,580 nodes. Four elements were taken in the thickness direction. The tools are assumed to be rigid and are described with analytical contours. The blank holder force was set to 116.5 kN which is one-fourth of the total measured blank holder force. A penalty-based contact algorithm is selected to describe contact. A constant Coulomb friction coefficient of 0.06 was chosen. The friction coefficient is low due to the fact that the sheets are galvanized and lubricant was applied in the process.

The simulations were carried out with the in-house implicit finite element code ‘Dieka’ using a direct solver. Three types of simulations were carried out; without a damage variable, with an isotropic (scalar) damage variable, and with an anisotropic (tensorial) damage variable.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Two simulation outputs were compared with the experimental results, i.e. the punch force–punch displacement curves and the strain distribution on the inside surface of the cross-die product.

sec.title: Punch Force–Punch Displacement Curves
sec.p:
Figure 8 shows the comparison of the simulated force–displacement (F–d) curves with experimental force displacement curves for the cross-die test. The F–d curves obtained from the simulations do not deviate until the damage threshold is reached. The F–d curve from the simulation without damage starts to deviate from the F–d curves from the simulations with damage around a punch displacement of 25 mm. The F–d curve from the simulation without damage clearly gives a stiffer response and a delayed necking, thus over predicting the critical punch displacement for the cross-die test with the given process parameters. Figure 8.
Comparison of the punch force–punch displacement curves for the cross-die test.

The F–d curves obtained from the isotropic damage and anisotropic damage simulations remain almost on top of each other. A slight deviation can be observed at the end. The isotropic damage simulation necks slightly earlier and gives a slightly softer response compared to the anisotropic simulation. The isotropic damage is expected to produce a more severe effect compared to anisotropic damage. The reason is that it effects the stress-carrying capacity in all directions by the same amount. Despite of the more severe effect of isotropic damage, only a slight difference is observed in the F–d curves obtained from isotropic and anisotropic damage models because damage develops in a very small region of the complete product and the contribution of the local stresses of this region to the global forces are very small. Nevertheless, both these curves predict the localization to occur around a punch displacement of 38.3 mm which is just below the critical punch displacement obtained from the experiments.

There are many uncertainties involved in the simulations, which probably cause the deviation of simulation F–d curves from the experimental F–d curve. Among these uncertainties, friction is one of the most important factors. A relatively simple friction model with a constant friction coefficient has been used in the simulations. The friction development in the cross-die test is rather complex and depends largely upon the contacting area and pressures (Hol et al., 2010). Therefore, the friction coefficient varies from one region to another and also evolves during the drawing process. Another factor which can play an important role in the deviation of the simulation results is the assumption of a constant blank holder force. As mentioned earlier in ‘Experiments’ section, eight load cells were used to measure the actual blank holder force. There was a variation in the blank holder force from one location to another, which can have an effect on the punch force. The difference between the maximum and the minimum measured blank holder forces in different locations was almost 7 kN. Another assumption made in the simulations is that the tools cannot deform. This assumption can also have a significant effect on the simulation results (Lingbeek etal., 2008).

sec.title: Strain Distributions
sec.p:
The strain distribution was measured on the inner surface (facing the punch) of the blank. The strain distribution presented in this article is taken from the experiment which reached the critical punch displacement of 39.6 mm, but did not localize. Comparisons were made on five sections which represent different stress states and involve strain path changes. Figure 9 shows the five different sections. Sections RD0 and TD1 contain the region, where failure occurs. Almost a plane strain condition occurs at the die radius in these sections. Section Diag2 contains the region with the highest strain. Since this region is mainly under shear, failure does not occur in this region. The other two sections RD3 and TD4 are the regions under biaxial tension. These regions are more stable than others. Figure 10 shows the comparison of the major strain distributions for three sections, i.e. RD0, Diag2, and RD3. The strains measured in the experiments at sections TD1 and TD4 are almost similar to the strains in the sections RD0 and RD3, respectively. This is due to the fact that the material is almost isotropic. It also justifies the use of Von Mises yield criterion in the simulations. The damage values were found the highest in the regions with a plane strain condition. This is in agreement with experimental results as the product localizes and develops a crack in this region. The maximum principal damage value is plotted for the simulation with anisotropic damage. Thedamage values obtained from the simulations with isotropic and anisotropic damage are almost the same. The strains obtained from all three simulations are in very good agreement with the experimental strain distribution away from the localized region. The experiment and the simulation without damage did not localize at this punch depth; therefore, they show good agreement within the localized region as well, whereas the simulations with damage, got localized at this punch depth and thus shows higher strains in the localized region in the section RD0 Figure 10(a). The simulations with damage show a failure at this punch depth which was observed in another experiment, whereas the simulation without damage failed to predict failure. The strains obtained from the isotropic damage simulation are slightly higher. As already discussed in ‘Validation of the parameters’ section, the isotropic damage is known to produce a more severe effect. Localization was observed only in the sections RD0 and TD1 in the simulations with damage. Therefore the strains are in very good agreement in the other two sections, i.e. Figure 10(b) and (c). The location of localization is in good agreement with that of the experiment with the slight crack. The failure is found to be in the region near to the plane strain condition. Figure 9.
Sections taken for comparison. Figure 10.
Strain distribution along different sections: simulations vs experiment: (a)Section RD0, (b) Section Diag2, and (c) Section RD3.

sec.title: Crack Propagation Direction
sec.p:
Figure 11 compares the location of maximum damage obtained from the simulations to the actual location of the crack in the experiments. The isotropic and anisotropic damage models predict the same location of crack initiation. The prediction of the location is in good agreement with the experiments. Figure 11.
Comparison of the location of maximum damage in simulations with the crack location.

A good damage model shall predict the crack direction reasonably accurate. This aspect of the model becomes important when crack propagation is included in the simulation. A scalar damage variable is used in isotropic damage models; therefore, the information regarding the direction cannot be obtained from the damage variable. A common approach is to take the crack propagation plane orthogonal to the maximum principal stress direction. This assumption is good enough for a proportional load condition. If the material undergoes nonproportional load path changes, then using the principal stress direction to determine the crack propagation direction may not give accurate results. This proposition can be shown from the cross-die test simulation.

In the experiments, the crack direction was almost in the transverse direction, which is perpendicular to the rolling direction. Note that due to a slightly higher draw in next to the edge, the rolling direction, in the simulations, is not horizontal. This gives a slightly skewed element with the angle between the edge and rolling direction to be almost 87o. This effect can be minimized by either selecting a very fine mesh at the edge or by considering a half or full model instead of a quarter model.

It is very interesting to see if, despite the-above mentioned effect, the damage models used in the simulations can predict the crack to grow in the correct direction. In the isotropic damage model simulation, the in-plane stresses were used to determine the angle of the maximum principal stress. The crack propagation direction is orthogonal to this angle. Figure 12(a) shows the variation in the angle orthogonal to the maximum principal stress for the isotropic damage model. The values of the stress components are taken at the node where the highest damage value occurs. The crack angle at failure is found to be almost 68° which deviates by 19° from the crack direction obtained in the experiments (Figure 11). In the anisotropic damage model, a damage tensor is used as the damage variable and therefore the principal damage direction can be obtained from this variable. The plane normal to the direction of the principal damage will give the crack direction. Figure 12(b) shows the damage components and the angle orthogonal to the maximum principal damage direction. The values of the damage components are taken at the node where the highest damage value occurs. The angle has been calculated based on the in plane components only. The direction ‘z’ represents the thickness direction. The crack angle at failure is found to be 83°. This value predicts the crack to grow at an angle of 4° from the edge which is much closer to the crack direction obtained from the experiments. Figure 12.
Crack propagation direction prediction: (a) isotropic damage model. and (b)anisotropic damage model.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: The Lemaitre's isotropic and anisotropic damage models were implemented in an implicit finite element code. The model was modified by making the damage parameters a function of strain rate. The damage evolution wasalso modified to achieve different damage behaviors under tension and compression stress states. The modified model was used to predict failure in cross-die tests for the AHSS DP600. The simulation without damage failed to predict failure at the actual critical punch depth. The simulations with the modified isotropic and anisotropic damage models predicted failure at the actual punch depth and location as observed in the experiments. The isotropic damage model gives slightly conservative results. The crack direction predicted from the isotropic damage model simulation deviates from the experiments, whereas the anisotropic damage model simulation predicted the crack direction more accurately. The difference found in the crack direction prediction of isotropic and anisotropic damage models is attributed to the nonproportional strain paths involved in the cross-die test.

All the damage parameters for DP600 were obtained from uniaxial tests. These parameters were successfully used to predict failure in a drawing product with a variety of triaxialities ranging from compression to biaxial conditions. The failure was predicted in a region with plane strain condition at almost the exact critical punch depth found from experiments.

ack.title: ACKNOWLEDGMENT
ack.p: This research was carried out under the project number M61.1.08308 in the framework of the Program of the Materials Innovation Institute (M2i) (www.M2i.nl).

sec.title: Derivative of Fourth–order Operators Q and M
sec.p: The fourth-order tensor ‘Q’ is used to define the function (77) where A is any second-order damage tensor and H the second-order damage effect tensor.

Using the definition of deviatoric part of a tensor, we can rewrite (77) as (78) Using the tensor identity (79) and knowing that H is symmetric, we can rewrite (78) as (80) Equation (80) shall hold for any second-order tensor A; therefore, (81) (82) (83) rearranging the parenthesis (84) Using the identity given in Equation (79) (85) (86) (87) Now using index notation to eliminate I4 from H· I4· H. (88) So the non-zero components are only for the conditions m = k and n = j (89) δkk and δjj are unity for all values of k and j; therefore, (90) which can be defined as a special tensor multiplication (as mentioned in Equation (29)) (91) Equation (87) can now be written as (92) The fourth-order tensor M is used to define the function (93) Using Equation (92), we can rewrite Equation (93) as (94) using the definition for deviatoric part (95) (96) (97) (98) Using Equations (90) and (91) (99) Carrying out the same simplifications as was done from Equations (83) – (87), we get (100) Substituting in Equation (99), we get (101) Rearranging (102) (103)

sec.title: Derivatives of Damage Effect Tensor H and H2 with Respect to Damage
sec.p: Differentiating ‘H2’ with respect to damage (104) Taking (105) gives (106) Using the tensor identity (107) we can write (108) Since D is symmetric, D' is also symmetric. (109) (110) (111) Using Equations (90) and (91), we can write (112) which is the derivative of H2 w.r.t D.

Now using Equation (112) to find the derivative H w.r.t D. (113) Using the tensor identity (114) we can write (115) (116) (117) (118) Using index notation to simplify Equation (118). (119) (120) The non-zero component are only for j = m. (121) since δjj is unity for all values of j thus (122) using the definition of the special tensor multiplication given in Equation (91) (123) and similarly (124) Now Equation (118) gives (125)
